results.title: Overspill
results.creator_credit: Mort Ransen, John Kemeny, Tom Daly, National Film Board of Canada and Svenska filminstitutet
results.brief_description: A film about Norrbotten, in northernmost Sweden, where industrial and agricultural patterns have changed and people are being relocated in industrial towns far from the life they have loved. In a series of interviews we meet people who have known the dignity of independence and who have suddenly become welfare cases. The film asks: Are their lives being improved? How can we reconcile human values and economic needs?

results.title: Overseas and undersold. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Bob Hill, Paul Hawker, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Part one of a two part series examining Australia’s international relations with overseas markets. Each episode gives a detailed background to individual markets and territories, as well as examining the financial opportunities available to Australian business. The series also examines mistakes made by Australian business in pursuing international competitiveness. Includes interviews with business leaders, economists and politicians. This volume examines the economies of Japan, Europe, China, India and the United Kingdom.

results.title: Decades of steam: the 1930's, the depression
results.creator_credit: Jeremy English and Ian Allan Limited
results.brief_description: This the second in the series of five videos tracing the story of steam locomotives during the middle of the 20th century. In this episode we look at the steam locomotive during the cold years of the depression. For the railways it was a period of austerity as they tried to meet the competition of the roads. The “Big Four” embarked on massive steam locomotive construction programs to replace the many different types inherited in 1923, although the Southern pursed electrification in order to eliminate steam. We visit familiar and not-so familiar locations to see steam at work, from the great main lines to the rural branches including Ireland which had 3 railways of its own and the Isle of Wight. Narrated by Ken Morgan.

results.title: Decades of steam : the 1960's, the final years
results.creator_credit: Jeremy English and Ian Allan Limited
results.brief_description: This is the fifth in the series of five videos tracing the story of steam locomotives during the middle years of the 20th century. In this episode we look at the 1960’s to see the end of steam locomotion on the public railway network in Great Britain. We see the last years of main line steam, the cruel blows of the Beeching “axe”, we see many branch lines destroyed forever, and the scrapping of their trains. Main line electrification and dieselisation would make even the famous “Duchesses”, “Kings” and “Bulleid Pacifics” redundant. However, a small gleam of light appeared on the horizon as railway preservation got underway, but after 11 August 1968 only one steam locomotive, the Flying Scotsman, was allowed to see out the decade working on the main lines. Narrated by Ken Morgan.

results.title: Decades of steam : the 1950's, setting the scene
results.creator_credit: Jeremy English and Ian Allan Limited
results.brief_description: This is the fourth in the series of five videos tracing the story of steam locomotives during the middle of the 20th century. In this episode the steam locomotive was seen as an anachronism which had to be replaced by “modern” power. However, British Railways had over 20,000 steam engines at the beginning of the decade, to which it added a further 999 examples- the well known Standard types. We trace the last full decade of steam locomotive development by examing each of the regions of British Railways, setting the scene for steam’s final years. Narrated by Ken Morgan.

results.title: Decades of steam : the 1940's, austerity and nationalisation
results.creator_credit: Jeremy English and Ian Allan Limited
results.brief_description: This is the third in the series of five videos tracing the story of steam locomotives during the middle years of the 20th century. In this episode the story of steam locomotives is taken through the end of independence into the early days of Nationalisation. The first half of the decade saw the railways at the forefront of the war effort, from which the black painted steam locomotives emerged bloodied but unbowed, still the principal power force on the railways. 1948 was to see a unified system, with Nationalisation. We see them on trial and bearing their new owner’s name in full - “British Railways”. We see postwar type engines and also some prewar survivors including the most radical of all, the Bulleid Pacific of the Southern. Narrated by Ken Morgan.

results.title: Overseas and undersold. Part 2
results.creator_credit: Bob Hill, Paul Hawker, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Part two of a two part series examining Australia’s international relations with overseas markets. Each episode gives a detailed background to individual markets and territories, as well as examining the financial opportunities available to Australian business. The series also examines mistakes made by Australian business in pursuing international competitiveness. Includes interviews with business leaders, economists and politicians. This volume examines the economies of Thailand, New Zealand, the Middle East and the United States. The last episode of this volume is a summation of the changes in Australian markets over the last decade.

results.title: Decades of steam : the 1920's, the big four
results.creator_credit: Jeremy English and Ian Allan Limited
results.brief_description: This is the first in the series of five videos tracing the story of steam locomotives during the middle years of the 20th century. In this episode we look at the great amalgamation - the grouping - of the Victorian companies in 1923 to form the “Big Four” railways: the Great Western, the Southern, the London, Midland and Scottish and the London & North Eastern. Using previously unseen archival film of the 1920’s, we examine the stock inherited by the “Big Four” and then look at the first new types introduced by the “Big Four”. Many rare scenes are shown and many locomotives shown including the Great Western “Dukes”, the “Lord Nelsons”, the “Atlantics” and the A1 “Pacifics”. Narrated by Ken Morgan.

results.title: Out: stories of lesbian and gay youth
results.creator_credit: David Adkin, Silva Basmajian and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film explodes some of the myths that provide the foundation for homophobia. It offers insight into the world of several gay and lesbian youth and looks at the people in their lives, identifying some of the difficulties gay youth face. The film attempts to break the damaging silence surrounding sexual orientation and sexual differences.

results.title: Dealing with Discipline Problems (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Jim Thornton and Dave Bell Associates
results.brief_description: A dozen discipline situations filmed at three of Dr Glasser’s model “schools without failure” demonstrates how teachers apply “success concepts” of reality therapy in everyday practice.
